title: "Development" or "Production" - how to find out?
body:
<!--
  Note: if the issue is about documentation or the website, please file it at:
  https://github.com/reactjs/reactjs.org/issues/new
-->

**Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?**

Primary just a question / secondary maybe a tiny feature request

**Question**

Is there an official way to find out whether the imported React package is the development or the production module ("react.development.js" vs. "react.production.min.js")?

Obviously you can do something like:
```javascript
const isProduction = React.Component.name !== 'Component';
```
... but I think we all agree that this is a really evil solution.

If the answer is "no" - then the question is: 
Would it be possible to add something like
```javascript
React.environment = 'development';
```
respectively
```javascript
React.environment = 'production';
```
(or something similiar) to the React object?

**Why is this useful?**
I'm sure your first thought will be: Why not just use the usual "Webpack / process.env.NODE_ENV" stuff?
But assume you have some React add-on library: This library itself has two different packages depending on the environment (e.g. "fancy-react-addon.development.js" vs "fancy-react-addon.production.min.js").
Also assume that it does (for whatever reasons) not make sense (or maybe it's not even allowed), to use React's development module in combination with the production module of your add-on library or vice versa. Then it would be great if directly on import an error is thrown if the module combination is invalid (independent of Webpack or process.env.NODE_ENV - because maybe the user of the add-on library will use some other tools).

```javascript
// Assume that this is "fancy-react-addon.production.min.js"

if (React.environment !== 'production') {
    throw new Error("You have to use React's production packages [... some details ...]");
}
```
Of course there are also some other use cases where this feature would also be handy or even necessary, but I hope the above use case is already convincing.

**Which versions of React, and which browser / OS are affected by this issue? Did this work in previous versions of React?**
 
16.2.0
